Hi!

If this is out of scope for this mailinglist, I'd be happy to take it to
private email, though I am using NEAT to evolve my strategies.

> There may be some value in using returns over the various periods,
> rather than average prices.

That's interesting, I'll consider that. Hm... how do you calculate the
return over a 14 day period, the price of day 1 - the price of price 14?

> I'd also consider some form of volatility
> measure - the standard deviation of the logs of the returns would be a
> pretty typical value.

I did some volatility calculations in my previous attempts, I'll get back
to why I gave it up below
 
> What is/are your output(s)? Buy/Sell? Predicted future price? 

Buy/Sell indications. >0.5 means wants to own <0.5 doesn't want to own. So
if it's owning and decides it doesn't want to own any more, it sells.

I tried many methods, but this one worked best for me. I tried different
strategies for buying / selling. I tried short positions, I tried mixing
short and long, I tried numerous others.

About short positions; 

* Short positions have an upside that is limited to 100% but their
downside is unlimited (as in you can lose an unlimited amount of money,
though the brokerage will forcibly sell your shares if it starts looking bad)

* Long positions have a downside limited to 100% but an upside that's
unlimited. I prefer long positions.

One input is "is owning stock now" which encourages longterm investments
because my fitness is somewhat profitability based. 

My fitness function including transaction costs _and_ it buys above open
and sells below open which further punishes trades but has the benefit of
being conservative. Something like 

Buy := Open + (High-Low)/x
Sell := Open - (High-Low)/x

You can't expect to buy on Open.

> Bear in
> mind that a short-term prediction may lead to frequent trading, which,
> unless you can deliver substantial returns will lead to commissions
> and bid-offer spreads eating up your profits.

I find that infrequent trading is more of a problem in my current
simulations than frequent trading. And it's a big problem, because on a
long time series (10 years), it's easy to pick 10 good buy spots and 10
good sell spots and earn fantastic profits, but it's harder to pick 100
such spots. 

And if you evolve something that trades well once in 10 years, that's less
likely to perform well out of bounds than something that trades well 1000
times in 10 years.

Currently, I severely punish infrequent trading because I view it as a
form of overfitting.

> This is a valuable (and profitable) system in a trending market,
> although it typically boils down to "it's going up - buy, then sell
> when it stops going up". It tends to be awful in a sideways market.

Yes, and the definition of long term vs short term will control how
profitable it is - values that will differ from period to period. Thus,
it's easy to create a long term/short term system that performs well in
bounds, but performs poorly out of bounds (even in a trending market)
because the cycles are faster or slower than the training period.

Sideways markets are a bitch, there's no two ways about it.
 
> Momentum and Relative strength are often useful in such markets. I
> never had much luck with more "exotic" indicators (stochastic
> thingies, oscillators and the like) although maybe I didn't calculate
> them correctly.
>
> Are you providing less correlated market information?Stock/sector
> indices? Interest/currency rates? Economic indicators? What about less
> obvious stuff: the price of oil/gold, say? The current FIFA ranking of
> the national football team? The Big Mac index?

Here I'm returning to why I gave up volatility;

my initial attempts (years back) presented each strategy with dozens of
indicators, including: Forecast using linear regression, Momentum,
Relative Strength Index, Money Flow Index, Accumulation / Distribution...
(there were a lot more). My thinking was that more data is better.

My conclusion after extensive testing is that more data tends to lead to
overfitting. I was using Genetic Programming at the time, but I think the
argument holds for NEAT also; 

* More data makes each situation unique in one way or another. that means
that the combination of data can be used to indentify a particular day
that's good for buying or selling.  This makes strategies very specific.

* Less data makes each situation less-unique (ooh, an oxymoron!), which
makes strategies more generic.

* Generic strategies are good, because they can be applied to unknown
data, specific strategies are bad, because they can only be applied to the
data that they're specific to.

Reducing the number of indicators improved performance in my recollection.

The question is - which indicators to use and what fitness function to
use. I tried a dozen different fitness functions also. Max drawdown, max
profit, max profit / max drawdown etc.

> > I'm hoping to open up the discussion again and see if there are any
> new
> > cool ideas floating around. The two indicators CloseRateAvg7,
> > CloseRateAvg14 open up for this type of strategy.
> 
> I'm curious about seeing the effects of having the model output a
> "confidence" value.  I like the idea a lot, but haven't any concrete
> results to show usefulness or otherwise.

Well, if it's not confident that owning the stock is a good idea, it gives
it a <0.5 value. My original system was far more complex than this, but
that's the gist of it.

> I can go on about this stuff until you're asleep - I spent  a lot of
> time (and CPU days) some years back trying to evolve fixed-topology
> networks for stock trading. I suspended operations due to (a) lack of
> easily-available/cheap data (b) inadequacy of approach - NEAT wasn't
> around (c) lack of time (d) something else I've forgotten just now.

I spent months working on my system, and I traded it for a couple of weeks
using about $10k. It actually performed as simulated, though it lost money
for the period I was testing it (both in simulation and in the real world).

Each day at three I'd perform trades as the system instructed me (that was
9 NY time). One day, just before I was about to place my orders, DATEK
went off the air for no apparant reason, it was very weird. That was
september 11:th 2001, you all know what happened next. The next day that
the marked was open I took the money of the market and the general marked
downturn meant that I had to use the money for other things. Haven't
traded the system since. But I'd like to get into it again.

> There are definitely companies out there that have invested heavily in
> AI-inspired trading strategies. DE Shaw is one, part of what is now
> UBS is another.

My experience is this; it's near impossible to come up with a single
strategy that can trade a single stock profitable, out of bounds. 

I'm not saying that AI trading isn't possible though...

cheers,
mattias
